text: Hi, I'm Francis,
the host of this show "Cooking with Dog."
First, dilute the nigari tofu coagulant
with an equal amount of lukewarm water.
This will help to mix the nigari
and the soy milk quickly and evenly.
Next, heat the soy milk in a pot.
We recommend using extra thick plain
soy milk with over 12% soy solids.
If this kind of soy milk isn't available,
reduce regular plain soy milk by 20 to 30%
by heating it slowly.
Make sure to keep stirring the soy milk
to avoid forming any film.
When the temperature of the soy milk reaches
75 째C (167 째F), turn off the burner.
If it exceeds the right temperature,
make sure to cool it down to 75 째C (167 째F).
While quickly stirring the soy milk,
add the nigari coagulant.
Be careful not to over-mix the mixture
otherwise the tofu will not have a smooth texture.
Cover and let it sit for about 10 minutes.
Now, the tofu has firmed up.
Strain the tofu with a mesh strainer
covered with a paper towel.
Wrap the tofu
and gently press it to help remove the excess water.
Ladle the tofu into a bowl.
Top with the chopped spring onion leaves,
grated ginger root
and bonito flakes.
Finally, pour on the dashi soy sauce or regular soy sauce.
The amount of nigari tofu coagulant should be
about 1 percent of the soy milk
but it varies depending on the product
so follow the instructions on the package.
The taste of tofu really depends on the ingredients
so make sure to use delicious soy milk
and good tasting water.
Good luck in the kitchen!
